questions.text: Counter current mechanism is not seen in :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Eye Explanation: Counter current mechanism is seen in kidney (loop of henle and vasa recta), testes, intestine and limbs.

questions.text: In this leishman’s stained blood smear, identify the cell which is raised markedly in worm infestations:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Guyton 11/e pg436 A. lymphocyte B. Neutrophil C. Eosinophil D.Basophil Eosinophils are usually bilobed with brick red granules that are increased in worm infestation.

questions.text: The following image shows cell count in different squares of a neubauer’s chamber after charging with 20 times diluted blood . What is the leukocyte count:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 6000 Per cu mm Ref: Textbook of practical physiology by GK PAI 2/e pg57 Explanation: Each of the square has a dimension of 1mmx1mm When coverslip is kept over the chamber depth is 0.1mm Hence, Volume of one square=1x1x0.1 =0.1cmm Concentration of cells=n/Vxd (n=no of cells, V=volume of distribution, d=dilution) Cells in 4 corner squares= 25+35+40+20=120 Total Volume of 4 squares=4x0.1=0.4cmm Dilution factor=20 Wbc count=n/Vxd=120/0.4x20=6000cells/cmm

questions.text: In the following electron micrograph of sarcometer correctly identify the area labelled as “E”.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) I-Band Ref: Ganong 24/e Pg 99 Explanation:The area marked as E is the lighter and isotropic band called as I band. It contains dark, Zline at its centre (A: A band, B: Actin filament, C: Sarcomere width, D: H zone)

choices.text: Decreased output of salivary glands < 0.5 ml/min

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the salivary gland output in Sjogren’ssyndrome :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increase in Phosphate concentration Ref: Harrison’s 18/e Chap324, Ganong pg456 Explanation: Salivary analysis of Sjogren’s Syndrome: 1. Increased: Salivary sodium, chloride, IgA 2. Decreased: Salivary phosphate, Stimulated and unstimulated salivary flow rate.

questions.text: Where do the peripheral processes of spiral ganglion end
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) i.e c, which are inner hair cells. Ref: Ganong pg206-207 Explanation: The peripheral processes of spiral ganglia end at inner hair cells marked as C. There are 500 inner hair cells and 20,000 outer hair cells. A- Basilar membrane, B-outer hair cells, C- inner hair cells, D-vestibular membrane

questions.text: In the following sections of the adrenal gland, what hormone is secreted by the region marked as “A” ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aldosterone Ref: Ganongpg 355 Explanation: A- Zona Glomerulosa- secretes mineralocorticoid(Aldosterone) B- Zona Fasciculata- secretes glucocorticoids C- Zona reticularis- secretes adrenal androgens

questions.text: Endo cochlear potential is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) +85mV Ref: Guyton 11/e pa656 Explanation:Endocochlear potential is due to continual secretion of potassium ions into the scala media by striavascularis and is +85mv and the resting membrane potential of the hair cell is –60mv.

questions.text: Rapid source of energy by resynthesizing ATP for exercising muscles is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Phosphocreatine Ref: Guyton 13/e pg 1087, Ganong 24/e pg 106 Explanation: ATP stored in muscle and ATP from creatine phosphate called as phosphagensystem.It is a rapid source of energy during exercise which sustains energy needs for 8 to 10 sec.

questions.text: Change in sex hormone binding globulin will most affect levels of which of these hormones?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ans. a. Testosterone Ref: Ganong 24/e p424 Explanation: Testosterone binds to SHBG with higher affinity than estradiol. Hence, change in level of SHBG causes a greater change in free testosterone than in free estrogen level.

questions.text: Calcium absortion from gut is increased by all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Phytates, which are found in plant-based foods like whole grains, nuts, and seeds, are a major inhibitor of calcium absorption. They bind to calcium in the digestive tract, forming an insoluble complex that the body cannot absorb. This significantly reduces the amount of calcium available to be utilized by the body. Why Other Options Increase Calcium Absorption B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is crucial for calcium absorption. It promotes the synthesis of a protein in the intestines that acts as a carrier, transporting calcium from the gut into the bloodstream. Without adequate Vitamin D, calcium absorption is greatly impaired. C. Alkaline pH in gut: Calcium is absorbed more effectively in an alkaline (or basic) environment. The presence of an alkaline pH in the gut, particularly in the small intestine where most absorption occurs, keeps calcium in a more soluble form, making it easier for the body to take it up. D. Protein in diet: Dietary protein, particularly animal protein, can enhance calcium absorption. Certain amino acids in protein can form soluble complexes with calcium, which facilitates its transport across the intestinal wall. However, excessive protein intake can also lead to increased calcium excretion in the urine, so a balanced intake is key.

questions.text: Hyperpolrizingcycline nucleotide (HCN) gated channels have a role in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cardiac rhythm generation Ref: Ganong 24/e pg 523 Explanation: Hyperpolarizing Cycline Nucleotide(HCN) gated channels are present in SA and AV node which open in hyperpolarization phase. Current through HCN channels called as funny or pacemaker current play a key role in generation and modulation of cardiac rhythmicity.

questions.text: Migratory motor complexes in the gut reappear after intervals of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 90 mins Ref: Johnson's Physiology pg 490, Ganong 24/e pg 490 Explanation: Migrating Motor Complex (MMR) are initiated by motilin. They come 90-120min after meal at an interval of 90mins. They travel from the stomach to the ileum at rate of 5cm/min.

questions.text: Diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide is decreased in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Polycythemia Ref: Ganong 24/e pg 635 Explanation: Diffusion Capacity of CO(DLCO) Increased in: 1.Acute attack of Asthma 2.Alveolar haemorrhage 3.Polycythemia 4.Chronic Heart Failure 5.Exercise Decreased in: 1.Emhysema 2.ILD 3.Pulmonary hypertension 4.Shock/Acute Heart failure 5.Anemia

questions.text: In the Following graph, the curve A represents the normal relationship between Alveolar ventilation and pCO2, when pO2 is 100 mm Hg. When pH is changed from 7.4 to 7.3, where will the original curve shift?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ref: Guyton 11/e pg 519 Explanation: B and C: Progressive hypoxia without change in pH D: only pH change without additional hypoxia E: Hypoxia as well as pH change. In this case there is only change of pH without additional hypoxia hence curve will shift to D.

questions.text: Potential developed due to movement of freely diffusible ions across a semi-permeable membrane iscalculated using:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nernst equation Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 24/e pg9-10 Explanation: if a cell membrane is freely permeable to an ion the magnitude of potential difference of the ion at equilibrium is given by Nernst equation.

questions.text: Polysomnography contains all of the following tests except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Arterial pCO2 measurement Ref: Ganong 24/e pg 276 Explanation: Polysomnography incudes: 1.ECG 2.EEG 3.EOG 4.EMG 5.Pulse oximetry and heart rate 6.Snoring

questions.text: Which of the following hormones has a permissive action at the onset of puberty :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Leptin Ref: Gannong’sreview of medical physiology 24/e p 399 Explanation : critical body weight is must to be reached for puberty. Recently leptin which is satiety producing hormone, secreted by the fat cells, is linked between puberty and body weight

questions.text: Respiratory rhythm generation center is located at :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prebotzinger complex Ref: Ganong’s review of medical physiology 24/ pg 658 Explanation : the rhythmic respiration is initiated by small group of pacemaker cells, in the Pre botzinger complex , which is present on either side of medulla between nucleus Ambiguus and lateral nucleus. They discharge rhythmically.

choices.text: Decrease in heart rate on adrenaline administration after phentolamine has been given

questions.text: Which of these statements depicts vasomotor reversal of dale :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Decrease in heart rate on adrenaline administration after phentolamine has been given Ref: KD Tripathi: Essentials of medical pharmacology 6/e p 123 -Vasomotor Reversal of Dale: If Epinephrine is given with an Alpha blocker in a living system , there will be a decrease in BP due to unopposed Beta-2 action. - Vasomotor Re-reversal of Dale : If Epinephrine is given with a beta blocker in a living system, there will be a significant rise in BP due to unopposed Alpha-1 action.

questions.text: According to weber Fechner’s Law strength of stimulus perceived is directly proportional to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Intensity of stimulus Ref guyton’s physiology 11/e p 594 Weber Fechner law states that magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to log of intensity of stimulus.

choices.text: Length of the muscle at rest
length of muscle before and after the movement

questions.text: During voluntary movements Golgi tendon organ has an important role to play because it continuously Relays to the efferent neurons when change occurs in :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tension in the muscle Ref: Ganong’s review of medical physiology 24/e Pg 229 Explanation : Golgi tendon organ is present in series in the muscle, detect muscle tension, innervated by Ib afferent nerve fibres. it relaxes the muscle which was contracted , and thus protects it from injury, it is an example of bisynaptic reflex.

questions.text: Localization of the receptor of a hormone X is found to be in the nucleus . What is likely to be X ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Thyroxine , Ref: Ganong’s Review of medical physiology 24/e p300 Explanation : thyroxine has intracellular receptors in the nucleus, other hormones having intracellular receptors are estrogens, retinoic acid, sex steroids, glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids have receptors in the cytoplasm , whereas protein hormones have receptors on the cell membrane.

questions.text: In relaxed state chest wall and lung recoil are balanced at :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) FRC Explanation : At the end of inspiration during quiet breathing , the lung have a tendency to collapse and the thoracic cage has a tendency to expand. This interaction between the recoil of the lungs and the recoil of the chest can be demonstrated by a spirometer. When a pressure – volume curve is plotted, the pressure is zero that corresponds to the lung volume , FRC , also called as relaxing volume. Ref: Ganong’s Review of medical physiology 24/e p630

questions.text: A couple comes for evaluation of infertility . The HSG was normal but semen analysis revealed azoospermia . What is the diagnostic test to differentiate between testicular failure and vas deferens obstruction :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Serum FSH Ref. Ganong’s review of medical physiology 24/e p 427 Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) is a gonadotropin, a glycoprotein polypeptide hormone. FSH is synthesized and secreted by the gonadotropic cells of the anterior pituitary gland, and regulates the development, growth, pubertal maturation, and reproductive processes of the body. FSH and luteinizing hormone (LH) work together in the reproductive system. FSH is a 35.5 kDa glycoprotein heterodimer, consisting of two polypeptide units, alpha and beta. Its structure is similar to those of luteinizing hormone (LH), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). The alpha subunits of the glycoproteins LH, FSH, TSH, and hCG are identical and consist of 96 amino acids, while the beta subunits vary.

questions.text: Best index to measure cardiac afterload is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) - Cardiac output depends on both preload and afterload. The preload is defined by the venous return and left ventricular end-diastolic volume while the afterload is defined by the mean arterial pressure, which then further depends on total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: On standing from sitting position a person has fall in BP of 10mm Hg . After correction , the baroreceptor sets back the BP by 8 mm Hg with an error of 2 mm Hg . What is gain of the system :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 4 Ref: Guyton’s physiology 11/e p8 Gain = correction /error ; 8/2 = 4 mm of Hg.

questions.text: The following graph shows the transport kinetics of a solute transferred across cell membrane . What is the likely nature of the solute :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In Given graph substance is Glucose which gets transported through Facilitated Diffusion. Concentration is high outside the membrane and low inside the membrane. These substance is not able to transport through the cell. There are special group of proteins which carry the substance from outside the membrane to inside. These proteins are called carrier proteins. When carrier proteins get saturated graph becomes parallel to X-axis.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for BezoldJarish Reflex?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Serotonin Ref: Ganong, 25thed/p. 592, 662 BEZOLD-JARISCH REFLEX Intracardiac injections of chemicals like serotonin, vertridine, capsaicin, phenyldiguanide activates this reflex Afferents for this reflex travel through unmyelinated vagal c fiber endings The reflex responses are: Apnea followed by rapid breathing Hypotension Bradycardia Clinical importance of Bezold-Jarisch reflex This reflex is responsible for sinus bradycardia seen during myocardial infarction This reflex is one of the cause for profound bradycardia and circulatory collapse after spinal anesthesia.

questions.text: The oxygen carrying capacity of a 18-years-old boy with haemoglobin of 14g/dl is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 18 Ref. Ganong, 25thed/p.640 OXYGEN CARRYING CAPACITY OF BLOOD The theoretical maximum oxygen carrying capacity is 1.39 ml O2/g Hb, but direct measurement gives a capacity of 1.34 ml O2/g Hb. 1.34 is also known as Hüfner’s constant. The oxygen content of blood is the volume of oxygen carried in each 100 ml blood. It is calculated by: (O2 carried by Hb) + (O2 in solution ) = (1.34xHbxSpO2x0.01) + (0.023xPaO2) Where: SO2 = percentage saturation of Hb with oxygen Hb = haemoglobin concentration in grams pre 100 ml blood PO2 = partial pressure of oxygen (0.0225=ml of O2 dissolved per 100 ml plasma per kPa, or 0.003 ml per mm Hg) Ans. (c) 18 Ref. Ganong, 25thed/p.640 OXYGEN CARRYING CAPACITY OF HEMOGLOBIN Each gram of haemoglobin transport 1.34 mL of oxygen So, here in the question, its 14x1.34=18

questions.text: There are two kinds of loop control systems encountered in homeostasis. Feed forward homeostasis can be seen for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) temperature , 4th edition ,Bijlanipg 12 There is control system in our body that anticipates, corrective changes even before the actual stimulus is provided. Examples of feed forward control are : a) temperature control b) cephalic phase of gastric secretion c) role of cerebellum in motor coordination

questions.text: Which of the following functional proteins are not seen in the region marked in the image shown?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The above image is of cardiac muscle , which shows all intercellular junctions except tight junctions ( zona occludens).

questions.text: Slow wave potentials in GIT are produced by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation: the slow wave potentials in the GIT are the basic electric rhythm, which itself does not produce depolarization but the spike potentials superimposed over the depolarizing part of the BER can produce muscle tension. The slow wave or the basic electric rhythm is by the pacemaker cells of GIT, the interstitial ` cells of cajal

questions.text: The blood levels of a hormone are elevated during exercise and sleep as shown. Which hormone fits the description?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation : the hormone above is growth hormone, as it shows diurnal variation and level rises in NREM sleep, also its level is more in exercises.

questions.text: Potassium homeostasis is not affected by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Insulin causes K+ ions to enter into the cells, by stimulating sodium potassium pump. Insulin useful in treatment of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Increase in atrial volume leads to increase in heart rate. This is according to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : there are low pressure receptors in the atria that respond to increase venous return, increase in venous return ( volume overload) leads to stretching of the atrial stretch receptors and the heart rate increases .

choices.text: Increase in oncotic pressure of peritubular capillaries
Decrease in blood flow of peritubular capillaries

questions.text: If there is efferent arteriole constriction, what will not happen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Chapter 27, Guyton & Hall textbook of medical physiology 13th edition, Pg-339 EXP: 1. Afferent arteriolar constriction decreases renal plasma flow (RPF) and thus decreases GFR by decreasing hydrostatic pressure of glomerular capillary. so here, filtration fraction viz GFR/RPF undergoes no change. 2) Constriction of efferent arteriole increases hydrostatic pressure of glomerular capillaries and thereby increases GFR. But this happens only initially. Later, GFR decreases when eff. arteriole constricts to less than critical diameter. So, effect of efferent arteriole constriction on GFR is BIMODAL. Option d: osmotic pressure in capillaries increases due to increased filtration fraction, mild efferent arteriolar constriction leads to increase in GFR.

choices.text: Closure of the inactivation gates of Na+ channels
Closure of activation gates of Na+ channels

questions.text: Which one of the following is responsible for absolute refractoriness of a nerve fibre during an impulse.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Chapter 5, Guyton & Hall textbook of medical physiology 13th edition, Pg-66 exp: • Absolute refractory period: Corresponding to the period from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete. No stimulus, no matter how strong, will not excite the nerve during absolute refractory period Cause - inactivation gates of the Na+ channel are closed when the membrane potential is depolarized. They remain closed until repolarization occurs. No action potential can occur until the inactivation gates open • Relative refractory period: Begins from the remaining part of repolarization to the end of action potential Stronger than normal stimulus(suprathreshold stimulus) produces action potential in relative refractory period Cause - The K+ conductance is higher than at rest, and the membrane potential is closer to the K+ equilibrium potential and, therefore, farther from threshold; more inward current is required to bring the membrane to threshold

choices.text: It is located lateral to white rami communicates
It connects sympathetic ganglion to spinal nerve

questions.text: What is not correct for grey rami communicantes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Each spinal nerve receives a branch called gray ramus communicans from the adjacent paravertebral ganglion of the sympathetic trunk ,the grey rami communicans contains post ganglionic nerve fibres of the sympathetic nervous system which are unmyelinated fibers.

choices.text: It is a part of filtration barrier
It has a lamina rara and lamina dura

questions.text: What is incorrect about renal basement membrane?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The renal basement membrane contains type IV collagen.

choices.text: Stretching of elastic elements of Lung Parenchyma
Decrease in surface tension at air-water interface at higher lung volumes
Changes in surfactant density at different lung volumes
HeringBreur Reflex is operational at higher lung volumes

questions.text: Hysteresis is observed between the Deflation and inflation curves in a static isolated lung compliance diagram. What is the best explanation for this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The curve has inspiratory and expiratory curves which do not coincide ,this difference is called hysteresis. It exists as a greater transpulmonary pressure is required to open a previously closed airway owing to deficit of surfactant at the air water interface ,than to keep an open airway from closing , reflecting abundant surfactant.

questions.text: Slow wave potential originates in which part of intestine:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Guyton & Hall textbook of medical physiology, 13th edition, Ch-63, Page no-798 exp: • Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells • They form gap junctions with GI smooth muscles • They are mainly responsible for the “generation of Basic electrical rhythm (BER)” • Pacemaker cells in stomach are located in the midbody of the stomach along the greater curvature • In colon, they are located at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer

questions.text: Which group of nerve fibres are least susceptible to LA?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th E/P 1033 EXP: Sequence of block in nerve fibres in response to local anesthetics: A (gamma>delta>beta>alpha) > B > C

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) GFR = Kf x Net filtration pressure Net filtration pressure = [Pgc – Pbc] – [ Pi gc – Pi bc] • Increased renal blood flow and efferent arteriolar constriction increases Pgc and thus increase GFR • Renal stone in ureter increases P bc and thus decreases GFR • Decreased capillary oncotic pressure also increases GFR

questions.text: Baroreceptor is which type of feedback?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Baroreceptor mechanism is for regulation of blood pressure. It is a type of negative feedback mechanism. Baroreceptors arepresent in carotid sinus and aortic arch. Impulses from these reach NTS in medulla which controls heart rate by parasympathetic and sympathetic system.

questions.text: Identify the ions bases on conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Conductance of ion A is highest during the upstroke of action potential, ie the ion is Na+ • Conductance of ion B is highest during downstroke of action potential, ie the ion is K+

questions.text: Cell membrane of a cell with RMP of -90mV is freely ________.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: B has done more work than A
B has both preload and after load added to it.
The maximum tension generated will be in A.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the image given below-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Condition A is afterload. Condition B is preload

choices.text: ESV first decreases and then increases

questions.text: During exercise in physiological limits what is the effect on end systolic volume?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The increase in arterial pressure (increased ventricular afterload) that normally occurs during exercise tends to diminish the reduction in end-systolic volume; however, the large increase in inotropy is the dominate factor affecting end-systolic volume and stroke volume.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluting segment of kidney?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ascending limb of loop of henle and early part of DCT are diluting segments because they are impermeable to water and permeable to solutes only. The channel present is Na-K-2Cl cotransport.

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and post synaptic
Connexions are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.text: How an electrical synapse is different from a chemical synapse?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Cytoplasmic continuity is present between presynaptic and pot synaptic in electrical synapse • Direction of impulse is bidirectional in electrical synapse • Connexions are involved in electrical synapse • Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.text: Calculate net filtration pressure with the following data?? PGC-42mmHg piGC-12mmHg PBC-16mmHg. Assume that no proteins were filtered.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Net filtration pressure = PGC - PBC - PiGC + PiBC = 42-14 -24 +0 = +14

questions.text: Hormones which is/are under inhibitory control of hypothalamus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) prolactin secretion is inhibited by dopamine which is secrted by hypothalamus. Growth hormone secretion is inhibited by somatostatin which is secreted by hypothalamus

questions.text: Which hormone has permissive role in puberty:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Leptin is a 167 amino acid polypeptide secreted by adipose tissue. it facilitates release of GnRH via kiss peptins.

questions.text: Fiber reaching directly to Purkinje cell of cerebellum from?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fibres from inferior olivary nucleus reach directly to purkinje cells of cerebellum. Afferents bringing propioceptive input are of two types • Climbing fibres: brings propioceptive inputs from the body and enter via inferior olivary nucleus and synapse directly with purkinje cells and deep nuclei of cerebellum • Mossy fibres: Brings input from whole body and directly synapse with deep nuclei of cerebllum and granule cells.

questions.text: Which area is involved in below image which when helps to relieve pain in response to massage.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) the area marked as A is substantia gelatinosa. it contains lamina I and II. it releases pain inhibiting substances called enkephalins which relives pain in response to massage. this is known as gate control theory of pain

questions.text: Cell organelle absent in below structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Section shown above is of cardiac muscle which controls single central nuclei surroinded by juxta nuclear region. Juxta nuclear region is rich in golgi bodies, SER and mitochondria. lysosomes are absent in cardiac muscle.

questions.text: Transport of glucose inside intestine, which type of transport
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intestinal cells contaim Na+ - K+ ATPase pump on basolateral side which pumps Na+ outside the cell and lowers Na+ concentration insidethe cell. From the apical side Na+ comes in along with glucose through SGLT-! channels. this is an example of secondary active transport

questions.text: Weber Fechner law- sensation felt is proportional
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Weber fechner law S = K log I/Io S - sensation felt K - constant I - threshold intensity Io - intensity of stimulus percieved

questions.text: In a closed room full of smoke, a person dies due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is an example of CO posioning. CO has 200 times more affinity to hemoglobin. binding of CO increases affinity of remaining sites of hemoglobin to O2. thus O2 is not releases to the tissue and Hb-O2 curve shifts to left.

questions.text: What’s the best way to maintain blood flow to tissue?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) According to poiseuillehagen equation , blood flow across the vessel is diectly proportional to fourth power to radius of the vessel.

choices.text: High control and less skilled movements
More muscle fibre units present in the movement

questions.text: Maximum area of representation in a homunculus signifies?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Homunculus is representation of various body parts in the cortex and it is in the shape of inverted man. representation is larger for the body parts requiring more precision. largest representation in motor homunculus is vocal cords > muscles of mastication> thumb. largest represenation in sensory homunculus is of face.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct formula to calculate minute volume?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Minute ventilation is volume of air inhaled or exhaled in one minute. Minute ventilation = RR x Tidal volume

questions.text: Correct statement regarding the role of vasa recta:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vasa recta are the blood vessels which are a part of counter current mechanism in kidney Counter cuurent system • Counter current multiplier: loop of henle which absorbs solute from lumer and creates interstiatial medullary hyper osmolality • Counter current exchanger: vasa recta which maintains the medullary hyper osmolality. • Medullary hyper osmolality is necessary to maintain concentration of urine.

choices.text: Increased hydrostatic pressure in bowman capsule
Decreased oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries
Increased oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries
Decreased hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries

questions.text: Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) will be increased if:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The forces in glomerulus favouring filtration are • PGC ie glomerular hydrostatic pressure • PiBCie colloid osmotic pressure of bowmans capsule The forces which oppose filtration are • PBC ie hydrostatic pressure of bownmans capsule • PiGCie glomerular colloid osmotic pressure

questions.text: Transthoracic compliance formula:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Trans thoracic pressure = alveolar pressure – atmospheric pressure .trans thoracic compliance is change in volume divided by transthoracic pressure C = ?V/ transthoracic pressure

questions.text: Normal dead space to tidal volume ratio is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vd/Vt = PaCO2 – PeCO2 / PaCO2

questions.text: A muscular man weighing 70 kg has haematocrit of 45%, what would be his plasma volume?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The plasma volume for the man would be approximately 2695 ml. Here is a step-by-step breakdown of the calculation: Step 1: Estimate Total Blood Volume The total blood volume is not given directly, but it can be estimated based on body weight. A common approximation for adult males is that total blood volume is about 70 mL per kilogram of body weight. Total Blood Volume = Body Weight × 70 mL/kg Total Blood Volume = 70 kg × 70 mL/kg = 4900 mL = 4.9 L Step 2: Calculate the Percentage of Blood that is Plasma Haematocrit is the percentage of blood volume that is composed of red blood cells. The remaining volume is primarily plasma. Haematocrit = 45% Plasma Percentage = 100% - Haematocrit Plasma Percentage = 100% - 45% = 55% or 0.55 Step 3: Calculate Plasma Volume Now, multiply the total blood volume by the plasma percentage to find the plasma volume. Plasma Volume = Total Blood Volume × Plasma Percentage Plasma Volume = 4.9 L × 0.55 = 2.695 L 2.695L X 1000= 2695ml

questions.text: What is the expected mixed venous oxygen tension, in mmHg, in a normal adult after breathing 100% oxygen for 10 minutes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Normal value of EPO (IU/L) is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normal value is between 3.7 to 36 IU/L Best answer here becomes option A

questions.text: Regulation of smooth muscle tone is persistently influenced by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sarcoplasmic reticulum is very poorly defined in smooth muscle . this is not a major mechanism of contraction. Latch bridge mechanism is only seen in smooth muscles. It is a very slow rate of actin – myosin cross bridge cycle which helps in sustained slow contaction of smooth mucles.

choices.text: No role in concentration of urine

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding urea?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Urea is reabsorbed through urea transporter channels present in PCT. Upto 52% of urea is absorbed in PCT. Urea helps to maintain medullary hyperosmolality and plays a role in urine concentration. No role of ADH in urea reabsorption

choices.text: All cells are same in nature
Are derived from neural crest cells
Active in mucosa and lymph nodes

questions.text: True regarding properties of dendritic cells
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dendritic cells are the major antigen presenting cells in the body. They are present in immature stage in blood and later they mature and migrate to skin, mucosa and lymph nodes. In skin they are known as Langerhans cells. They interact with B cells and T cells in lymph nodes.

questions.text: Normal cardiac index in an adult is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Cardiac index is defined as cardiac output per meter sq of body surface area. It is calculated as follows CI = CO / Total body surface area Normal cardiac index is 3.2 L/min/ m2

questions.text: In a measurement of cardiac output using the Fick principle, the oxygen concentrations of mixed venous and arterial blood are 16 mL/100 mL and 20 mL/100 mL, respectively. If the oxygen consumption is 300 mL/min, what is the cardiac output in liters per minute?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cardiac output can be calculated using ficks principle as follows CO= (O2 consumption ml/min)/(arterio-venous O2 diference ml/L) = 300 / 200-160 = 300/40 = 7.5 L/min

questions.text: If the heart rate of the person is 70/min, then duration of his cardiac cycle will be ____
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 70 heart beats -------- 60 sec 1 heart beat ---------??? Cardiac cycle duration = 60/70 = 0.8

choices.text: Minute volume = Respiratory rate X tidal volume

questions.text: What is the percentage of glucose absorbed in the S3 segment of PCT

questions.text: Glomerular filtration barrier is formed by all of the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Glomerular filtration barrier is made up of: I. Glomerular capillary endothelium which is fenestrated upto 70 to 90 nm II. Glomerular basement membrane which is made up of type IV collagen and composed of proteoglycans. III. Podocyte layer which is visceral layer of bowmans capsule. It sends finger like projections into the glomerular basement membrane and forms filtration slits . it doesn’t have fenestrations

questions.text: Apical membrane of PCT contains
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sodium-dependent glucose cotransporters (or sodium-glucose linked transporter, SGLT) are a family of glucose transporter found in the intestinal mucosa (enterocytes) of the small intestine (SGLT1) and the proximal tubule of the nephron (SGLT2 in PCT and SGLT1 in PST). They contribute to renal glucose reabsorption. In the kidneys, 100% of the filtered glucose in the glomerulus has to be reabsorbed along the nephron (98% in PCT, via SGLT2).

questions.text: Which of the following best describe ‘Anrep effect’?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anrep effect states increase in after load is directly proportional to cardiac contractility. And also directly proportional to inotropy. When u have increased aortic pressure ie afterload, it allows a compensatory effect from heart which allows increased contractility inorder to push the blood against the pressure.

choices.text: Increase in heart rate causes increase contractility
Decrease in heart rate leads to decrease contractility
Increase in heart rate leads to decrease in contractility
Decrease in heart rate leads to increase in contractility

questions.text: Which of the following is bowditch effect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bowditch effect is increase in heart rate will increase contractility of heart. The Bowditch effect is also known as the Treppe phenomenon, staircase phenomenon, or frequency-dependent activation. It refers to the idea that an increase in heart rate increases the force of contraction generated by the myocardial cells with each heartbeat despite accounting for all other influences.

questions.text: IP3 facilitates which of the ion entry into the cytoplasm

questions.text: Which of the following are the late effects of mountain climber except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) As the person acends to high altidute, he suffers from hypxia due to reduced atmospheric pressure and reduced partial pressure of O2.this is known as hypoxic hypoxia. This induces release of erythropoietin from kidney. He immediately does hyperventilation, which causes CO2 washout. This leads to respiratory alkalosis. The kidneys compensate for respiratory alkalosis in about 2 to 3 days, by increased secretion of HCO3. OO2 - Hb curve is shifted to right. At cellular level, there is increase in mitochondria and cytosolic enzymes

questions.text: In a measurement of cardiac output using Ficks principle, the O2 concentration of mixed venous and arterial blood are 16 and 20 in 100 ml respectively and o2 consumption is 300 ml/min. the cardiac output is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ficks principle states that the amount of substance taken up by an organ is equal to the arterial minus venous concentration of that substance multiplied by the blood flow to that organ. 300 ml/min = ( 20 – 16 ml/ 100ml ) x blood flow through lungs in one minute

questions.text: Lusitropy is negatively impacted by all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lusitropy refers to the heart's ability to relax during diastole. Factors that impair calcium removal from the cells, or increase intracellular calcium, generally impair lusitropy (slow down the relaxation phase). Increase in intracellular calcium increases contraction force, but decreases lusitropy, because it prevents the heart from relaxing properly. Now let's go through the options: A. Increase in catecholamines: Does not negatively impact lusitropy. Catecholamines (like adrenaline) actually improve both contraction and relaxation by enhancing calcium handling, thus increasing lusitropy. B. Defect in sarcolemmal calcium pump: Negatively impacts lusitropy. The sarcolemmal calcium pump helps remove calcium from the cell, and a defect would lead to calcium buildup in the cell, making it harder for the heart to relax. C. Defect in sodium-calcium exchanger: Negatively impacts lusitropy. This defect would also prevent proper calcium removal from the cell, impairing relaxation and reducing lusitropy. D. Increase in intracellular calcium: Negatively impacts lusitropy. More calcium inside the cell would enhance contraction but prevent proper relaxation, thus reducing lusitropy.

choices.text: Affinity of TBG to T4 > T3

questions.text: True about thyroid hormones
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) is a globulin protein that in humans is encoded by the SERPINA7 gene. TBG binds thyroid hormones in circulation. It is one of three transport proteins (along with transthyretin and serum albumin) responsible for carrying the thyroid hormones thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) in the bloodstream. Of these three proteins, TBG has the highest affinity for T4 and T3 but is present in the lowest concentration relative to transthyretin and albumin, which also bind T3 and T4 in circulation. Despite its low concentration, TBG carries the majority of T4 in the blood plasma. Due to the very low concentration of T4 and T3 in the blood, TBG is rarely more than 25% saturated with its ligand. Unlike transthyretin and albumin, TBG has a single binding site for T4/T3. TBG is synthesized primarily in the liver as a 54-kDa protein. In terms of genomics, TBG is a serpin; however, it has no inhibitory function like many other members of this class of proteins.

questions.text: Correct dyad of sensory receptor and sensation carried include(s)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (BD) Ref: Guyton 12th Ed/560 Explanation: Krause’s end bulbs or krows are rapidly adapting (phasic), encapsulated nerve terminals in skin, mucosa of oral cavity, conjunctiva, and other parts, consists of a laminated capsule of connective tissue enclosing the nerve terminal, branched, convoluted ending of an afferent nerve fiber; generally believed to be sensitive to touch and pressure. Pacinian corpuscle is a very rapidly adapting (phasic) touch receptor and can detect fast vibration upto 800 cps. Meissner’s corpuscles are rapidly adapting (phasic) touch receptors, specific for fine, well localized touch, slow vibration, texture, topognosis. Ruffini’s endings are slowly adapting (tonic) receptors and specific for touch and prolonged pressure. Merkel’s disc is a slowly adapting (tonic) receptor and can detect fine, well localized touch and texture.

Hemoglobin A2 may be increased in beta thalassemia or in people who are heterozygous for the beta thalassemia gene.HbA2 exists in small amounts in all adult humans (1.5-3.1% of all hemoglobin molecules) and is approximately normal in people with sickle-cell disease

choices.text: Ascending limb secretes water in lumen

questions.text: True statement(s) regarding loop of Henley in kidney is/are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (AB) Ans 3: AB Ref: Guyton 12th Ed/484; Ganong 25th Ed/701 Explanation: Water reabsorption In PCT, the fluid in tubule is isotonic, with osmolarity of 300 mosm/L Due to water moving out in descending limb of loop of Henle, the fluid becomes hypertonic, reaching as high as 1200 mosm/L As fluid enters ascending limb of loop of Henle, due to movement of Na and Cl outside, the fluid again starts becoming hypotonic. The fluid entering early DCT is always hypotonic Finally, osmolarity starts rising in late DCT due to Na and Cl movement to the outside. In terminal DCT and collecting tubules, the osmolarity changes according to water permeability, as governed by ADH. Under the influence of ADH (which increases only water reabsorption, not solutes), another 10-12% water is reabsorbed, thereby increasing the tonicity. Remember: Aldosterone acts on cortical collecting duct whereas ADH acts on medullary collecting duct

questions.text: True regarding CSF is/are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • CSF formation occurs in two stages (a) Stage 1: filtration of plasma into fenestrated capillaries of choroid plexus. (b) Stage2: active secretion by transport of Na+ and Cl- across epithelial membrane. It is mainly produced in stage 2 • Nutrients can pass directly through blood brain barrier. Hence CSF is nit a main source of nutrients for the brain. • Internal jugular vein compression has shown negligible decrease in cardiac output and negligible decrease in arterial pressure. Hence cerebral blood flow is reduced slightly and this increses brain volume by 6%. There is no change in CSF pressure.

questions.text: Viscosity of blood depends upon?

Fibrinogen causes increased erythrocyte sedimentation and thereby incresesviscousity of blood. • Age is not related to viscosity of blood.

choices.text: Descending limb is moderately permeable to sodium & urea.
Ascending limb is permeable to Sodium
Descending limb is impermeable to water
Ascending limb is permeable to water

questions.text: All of the following statements about exchange multiplier are true except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The descending limb of the loop of Henle, particularly the thin descending limb, is highly permeable to water. As the tubular fluid flows down into the progressively saltier (hypertonic) renal medulla, water is osmotically drawn out of the tubule into the medullary interstitium. This outward movement of water is a crucial step in concentrating the urine and is a defining characteristic of this segment of the nephron. Therefore, the statement that the descending limb is impermeable to water is false. Incorrect Options: Option (A. Descending limb is moderately permeable to sodium & urea.) Explanation: While the primary characteristic of the thin descending limb is its high permeability to water, its permeability to solutes like urea and, to a lesser extent, sodium, does increase as it extends deeper into the inner medulla. This contributes to the medullary osmotic gradient and urea recycling. Thus, the statement is generally considered true in its nuanced detail, especially compared to the clear falsehood of options C and D. Option (B. Ascending limb is permeable to Sodium) Explanation: This statement is true. Both the thin and thick ascending limbs are permeable to sodium. The thick ascending limb specifically utilizes active transport (e.g., the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter) to reabsorb large amounts of sodium (along with chloride and potassium) from the filtrate into the medullary interstitium. This active removal of solutes is fundamental to the countercurrent multiplier's function and the dilution of the tubular fluid. Option (D. Ascending limb is permeable to water) Explanation: This statement is false. The entire ascending limb of the loop of Henle (both thin and thick segments) is characteristically impermeable to water. This impermeability is essential for the countercurrent multiplier to work effectively. It allows solutes to be removed from the tubule without water following, thereby diluting the tubular fluid and maintaining the hypertonicity of the renal medulla. While this statement is also false, in the context of typical "except" questions, the descending limb's absolute need for water permeability (Option C's inverse) is often seen as a primary and critical distinction.

questions.text: With increase in age, which of the following is true for lungs?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pulmonary compliance increases With aging, the lungs undergo structural changes — most notably the loss of elastic tissue in the alveolar walls. This results in a reduction in elastic recoil, meaning the lungs become more distensible or "floppy." As a result, pulmonary compliance increases, allowing the lungs to inflate more easily. However, this increased compliance is physiologically not advantageous, as it leads to inefficient emptying of the lungs and air trapping. This is a hallmark age-related change in lung mechanics. Incorrect Option B: Residual volume decreases This is incorrect because residual volume (RV) increases with age, not decreases. As lung recoil diminishes and the strength of respiratory muscles weakens, the ability to forcefully exhale is reduced. This causes more air to be retained in the lungs after expiration, thereby increasing the residual volume. Therefore, this option is false. Incorrect Option C: Mucociliary clearance increases This option is also incorrect. Aging is associated with decreased mucociliary clearance due to reduced ciliary activity, altered mucus production, and thinning of airway epithelium. These changes impair the lungs' ability to clear inhaled particles and pathogens, making older adults more prone to respiratory infections. Hence, mucociliary clearance does not increase — it declines with age. Incorrect Option D: Fibrosis of interstitium decreases This is not true. In fact, fibrosis tends to mildly increase in the lung interstitium with age, even in the absence of overt disease. These fibrotic changes can contribute to a gradual decline in lung function and impaired gas exchange. So, fibrosis does not decrease as we age — it typically becomes more evident.

questions.text: Functional residual volume is measured
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Functional residual capacity (FRC), is the volume remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation. In a normal individual, this is about 3L. The FRC also represents the point of the breathing cycle where the lung tissue elastic recoil and chest wall outward expansion are balanced and equal

questions.text: In forceful expiration, which of the following neurons get fired?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In pons : Upper Pons: Pneumataxic Centre : Limits inspiration by inhibiting Apneustic centre i.e Rate of respiration is controlled by Pneumotaxic Centre. Increases Respiratory Rate. Lower Pons: Apneustic Centre : Prolongs inspiration - In medulla : A)Pre-Botzinger complex : Initiation of Respiration B) Dorsal Respiratory group (DRG) : Generates Ramp signal which results in steady rise in tidal volume C) Ventral Respiratory group ( VRG) : VRG has no role in controlling expiration at last ( passive process). VRG controls forceful expiration during excercise. The extra Respiratory effort during exercise is called as Expiratory drive or Overdrive Phenomenon.
